item.title: Comment on Toaster Settings Killed The Radio Star by jhtreasurechest9
item.dc:creator: jhtreasurechest9
item.content:encoded:
Whew. I almost missed the film clip. Damn that it comes around again and again!

On Wed, Apr 13, 2022 at 3:24 AM Nanette D. Massey wrote:

> Nanette D. Massey posted: ” The 1999 film Magnolia is an ambitious story > about an ensemble cast of characters, each having a very bad day of their > own without knowing their trials are all interconnected. One line weaves > ominously throughout: “we might be through with the past” >

item.title: Comment on Toaster Settings Killed The Radio Star by Lisa Lewis
item.dc:creator: Lisa Lewis
item.description: Thank you for sharing your first hand perspective on this issue, and being so open. It is painful to read, but not nearly as painful as it must be to live.
item.content:encoded: Thank you for sharing your first hand perspective on this issue, and being so open. It is painful to read, but not nearly as painful as it must be to live.

item.title: Comment on Toaster Settings Killed The Radio Star by Kathy L Kidd
item.dc:creator: Kathy L Kidd
item.description: Wow. So sorry he did not see the value in what you were offering. And the trauma Black women suffered that you describe is written in a way that sickens me in the gut and wrenches my heart. I know that is only a fraction of what you and other Black women feel so there is no way I can imagine what that pain must feel like. There are not sufficient words to say more.
item.content:encoded: Wow. So sorry he did not see the value in what you were offering. And the trauma Black women suffered that you describe is written in a way that sickens me in the gut and wrenches my heart. I know that is only a fraction of what you and other Black women feel so there is no way I can imagine what that pain must feel like. There are not sufficient words to say more.

item.title: Comment on Toaster Settings Killed The Radio Star by Elaine Rosen
item.dc:creator: Elaine Rosen
item.description: Excellent writing about a disturbing but not shocking incident. Why is it so difficult for people to understand their own racism and the mental abuse it causes? This total lack of insight and empathy is why you are so necessary! Please never give up trying to break through. We are all lucky to have the benefit of your mission.
item.content:encoded: Excellent writing about a disturbing but not shocking incident. Why is it so difficult for people to understand their own racism and the mental abuse it causes? This total lack of insight and empathy is why you are so necessary! Please never give up trying to break through. We are all lucky to have the benefit of your mission.

item.description: you are a warrior Nanette, and i am on your team. thanks for all you do

item.title: Comment on Howard’s Way by Guy welsher
item.dc:creator: Guy welsher
item.description: Apparently you’re not from Rochester or you’d know Howard lived and went to school in Penfield. Granted his living conditions weren't the best as his parents were agricultural workers and they lived in one of the outhouses . You would also know that the 64 riots started out as a block party and someone got out of hand and the citizens there called the police . When they went to arrest him the girlfriend victim recanted her story and riled up the crowd . I was a baby and lived a couple blocks down . I lived in the city till the early nineties. In the hood . What’s the graduation rate among black folks in Rochester and what is the single parent percentage ? The only institutional or structural racism is in your head .
item.content:encoded: Apparently you’re not from Rochester or you’d know Howard lived and went to school in Penfield. Granted his living conditions weren’t the best as his parents were agricultural workers and they lived in one of the outhouses . You would also know that the 64 riots started out as a block party and someone got out of hand and the citizens there called the police . When they went to arrest him the girlfriend victim recanted her story and riled up the crowd . I was a baby and lived a couple blocks down . I lived in the city till the early nineties. In the hood . What’s the graduation rate among black folks in Rochester and what is the single parent percentage ? The only institutional or structural racism is in your head .

item.title: Comment on What people are saying about my Sunday webinar series– by “We did everything adults would do. What went wrong?” | Nanette D. Massey
item.dc:creator: “We did everything adults would do. What went wrong?” | Nanette D. Massey
item.description: […] town without notice. The youngest, “April”, is as dark as me. Kelly told us in one of my Sunday webinar sessions of “April” being followed around at a children’s party by a white boy […]
